channel.title: Linked lists, explanation please
channel.description:
Somebody please explain linked lists to me, I've been tearing my hair out trying to implement one using an array in Java and I've just realised I don't even understand how they work.
So can someone explain for me a singly linked list?

item.title: Linked lists, explanation please
item.dc:creator: @zstars zstars
item.description:
@zstars wrote:

You could use a linked list to index the elements of an array in a specific order

Also, some data structures are often implemented as a bunch of arrays linked together. That way iteration is significantly faster, and insertion and removal is reasonable (and in fact, it is O(1) at the beginning and end of each composing array).

Read full topic

item.title: Linked lists, explanation please
item.dc:creator: @davidude36 Brolapse
item.description:
@davidude36 wrote:

abraham2119:

i have yet to see the advantages of using a linkedlist over an expandable list; much slower to access a certain element, occupies more memory, etc

abraham2119, this was for my computing class at college and therefore all theory, you’d probably never make a linked list in a real situation with an array, it’s just theoretical. So whether it is useful or not doesn’t matter.

Also abraham2119 protip: don’t feed the trolls.

Thanks everyone else for your help.

Read full topic

item.title: Linked lists, explanation please

when i said expandable list, i was referring to list that dynamically reallocate the initial block of memory allocated; ie arraylists

Read full topic

item.title: Linked lists, explanation please
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

I don’t really know what you mean by ‘expandable list’, since linked lists are by nature expandable.

No matter what though, there is not now and will never be the ‘perfect’ list data structure. There are uses for most to all of them, but in different circumstances different data structures perform better. Same thing applies to algorithms. Using search algorithms for example, quicksort is usually the fastest, but in the case of data that is almost sorted (ie, only a few elements out of place) quicksort is painfully slow and may take hours where something generally considered slow, like bubblesort, will complete in a manner of seconds. Understand?

Read full topic

item.title: Linked lists, explanation please
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

singly linked lists are built up of nodes. each node has some data assigned to it, and also a pointer to the next node. these pointers link the nodes together, hence linked list. doubly linked lists are the same, except that nodes also have a pointer to the previous node as well.

Read full topic
